docs.lead_paragraph: The National Academy of Sciences said today that Medicare, Medicaid and other government programs should reward high-quality health care by paying higher fees or bonuses to the best doctors, hospitals, nursing homes and health maintenance organizations. In a report requested by Congress, the academy said the federal government should establish standard measures of quality, assess the performance of each health care provider and publish comparative data for use by consumers.

headline.main: Study Tells U.S. to Pay More For the Best Medical Care

docs.abstract: National Academy of Sciences says six federal health programs should reward high-quality care by paying higher fees or bonuses to best doctors, hospitals, nursing homes and health maintenance organizations; says government should establish standard measures of quality, assess performance of each health care provider and publish comparative data for use by consumers; 100 million Americans are served by six programs in question: Medicare, Medicaid, Children's Health Service, Defense Department's Tricare program, veterans' health program and Indian Health Service (M)
docs.snippet: The National Academy of Sciences said today that Medicare, Medicaid and other government programs should reward high-quality health care by paying higher fees or bonuses to the best doctors, hospitals, nursing homes and health maintenance...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was started in a tenement on the Lower East Side. A handful of immigrant socialists, most of them Yiddish-speaking laborers, gathered in the Essex Street home of Sam Greenberg, a cloak maker, wanting to find a way to take care of one another through sickness and death as they tried to gain footholds in a formidable country. In the process, these newcomers hoped to ease their loneliness.

headline.main: Less Socialist, But Still Social; Circle Is Link to a Yiddish Past

docs.abstract: Workmen's Circle, founded in Lower East Side (NYC) tenement by Yiddish-speaking immigrant socialists, celebrates centennial and must confront organization's relevance in today's culture while clinging to traditions of past; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HealthSouth said yesterday that an investigation by an outside law firm into the recent stock sales of its chairman, Richard M. Scrushy, had found no evidence of wrongdoing and had cleared Mr. Scrushy of having insider information before he sold nearly $100 million in stock. But HealthSouth, which had said it would make the report on the investigation public, released only what it described as a concluding paragraph. And its release indicated that some words had been omitted even from that paragraph.

headline.main: Stock Sale Inquiry Exonerates Chairman of HealthSouth

docs.abstract: HealthSouth says investigation by outside law firm Fulbright & Jaworski into recent stock sales of chairman Richard M Scrushy finds no evidence of wrongdoing and clears Scrushy of having insider information before he sold nearly $100 million in stock; releases only part of report to public, but sends full report to Securities and Exchange Commission; HealthSouth hails findings as end to accusations facing Scrushy and says it expects SEC to make similar finding after it concludes probe; Fulbright & Jaworski has also examined how company handled May notice by Medicare that prompted change in its billing practices that led to earnings surprise (M)
docs.snippet: HealthSouth said yesterday that an investigation by an outside law firm into the recent stock sales of its chairman, Richard M. Scrushy, had found no evidence of wrongdoing and had cleared Mr. Scrushy of having insider information before he sold...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, was savoring a major victory this morning as he signed his first budget, in a ceremony just hours after the County Legislature's Democratic majority adopted the plan. But the celebratory mood lasted only a few moments. Mr. Suozzi, a Democrat, suddenly declared political warfare on the Republican lawmakers who had unanimously opposed the budget, calling them ''obstructionists'' and ''phonies.''

headline.main: Budget Passed, Nassau Leader Goes on Attack Against G.O.P.

docs.abstract: Nassau County, New york, County Exec Thomas R Suozzi savors major victory as county legislature approves his first budget, and lashes out at Republican minority that opposed measure; blames Republicans for nearly bankrupting county when they were in power and vows to destroy party machine and defeat machine politicians who 'ruined' county government (M)
docs.snippet: The Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, was savoring a major victory this morning as he signed his first budget, in a ceremony just hours after the County Legislature's Democratic majority adopted the plan. But the celebratory mood lasted only...

docs.lead_paragraph: George E. Pataki ran for governor in 1994 promising tax cuts, tougher criminal penalties, welfare reform and not much else. It was a conservative platform well suited to the year of the Gingrich revolution and it worked, as Mr. Pataki unseated Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Times have changed, and so, it seems, has Mr. Pataki. His signature issues lost their political bite in an era of economic expansion, falling crime and plummeting welfare rolls.
docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki of New York, Republican seeking third term, is being called counterfeit conservative by Independence Party candidate Tom Golisano and counterfeit liberal by Democratic challenger H Carl McCall; in 1994 Pataki ran on conservative platform, promising tax cuts, tougher criminal penalties and welfare reform; he seeks third term on platform of increased spending on schools and medical care, as friend to labor unions that once vilified him, as governor who has delivered gun controls and penalties for hate crimes and as backer of equal-rights law for gay people; political scientist Prof Gerald Benjamin calls Pataki pragmatic, opportunistic and very shrewd politically; review of Pataki's record reveals paradox, and his own words complicate task of assessing his record; on many issues, he has set out on fairly conservative course, then taken turn to left; detailed examination of his record on taxes, health care, environment, education, economic development, ethics and reform; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans reported today that third-quarter profit dropped 72 percent, hurt by costs from lawsuits over a 1997 decline in its share price. Net income fell to $23.8 million, or 26 cents a share, from $85.7 million, or 85 cents, a year earlier, Oxford said. The company, one of the biggest health insurers in the New York area, said revenue rose 15 percent, to $1.27 billion from $1.11 billion.
docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans reports third-quarter profit dropped 72 percent; net income fell to $23.8 million from $85.7 million; revenue rose 15 percent, to $1.27 billion from $1.11 billion (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the hope of winning quick passage and mayoral backing, City Council members said yesterday that they had negotiated a scaled-back compromise bill that would require some city contractors to grant higher pay to more than 50,000 employees. Under this ''living wage'' bill, pay for 50,000 home health aides would rise to a minimum of $8.10 an hour with health insurance, or $9.60 without health insurance, and to a minimum of $10 in 2006, from the current $7.50. The bill would also set minimum pay for 8,000 day care workers and nearly 1,000 workers with agencies dealing with cerebral palsy, many of them already earning more than $8.10 an hour.

headline.main: Council Offers Compromise On 'Living Wage' Measure

docs.abstract: New York City Council members negotiate compromise 'living wage' bill that would require some city contractors to grant higher pay to more than 50,000 employees in health care, day care and other sectors; home health aides would get $8.10 minimum per hour or $9.60 without insurance coverage, rising to $10 in 2006; scaled-back measure is in response to city's fiscal straits (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pfizer has agreed to pay $49 million to settle charges that a subsidiary defrauded the Medicaid program by overcharging for the cholesterol-lowering drug Lipitor, the Justice Department said today. Medicaid, the state-federal health insurance program for the poor, requires drug makers to pay quarterly rebates to states to account for discounts drug companies give to favored customers.

headline.main: Pfizer to Pay $49 Million in Fraud Case

docs.abstract: Justice Department says Pfizer Inc has agreed to pay $49 million to settle charges that subsidiary Parke-Davis Labs defrauded Medicaid program by overcharging for cholesterol-lowering drug Lipitor; Medicaid requires drug makers to pay quarterly rebates to states to account for discounts drug companies give to favored customers; Parke-Davis was accused of overstating best price for Lipitor in first and second quarters of 1999 by concealing $250,000 in discounts to managed care customer in Louisiana; Justice Department says unreported discounts allowed Parke-Davis/Warner-Lambert to retain more than $20 million in rebates owed to Medicaid; Pfizer agrees five-year corporate integrity agreement intended to prevent problems (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Humana said today that its third-quarter profit rose 20 percent as it added members and reaped gains from its unit that provides insurance for the military. Humana posted net income of $52.3 million, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter, compared with an adjusted net income of $43.5 million, or 26 cents a share, in the period a year ago.
docs.abstract: Humana says its third-quarter profit rose 20 percent; posts net income of $52.3 million for quarter, compared with adjusted net income of $43.5 million year earlier; revenue was $2.84 billion, up 8.8 percent from $2.61 billion year ago (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of the Tenet Healthcare Corporation fell 14 percent yesterday after an analyst cut his rating on the stock because of concern about government health care reimbursements to Tenet. The company said its profit outlook had not changed. Shares of Tenet, one of the largest hospital companies in the nation, fell $6.81, to $42.50. Tenet is more dependent than its rivals are on special Medicare payments for patients whose treatments cost much more than the average, a UBS Warburg analyst, Kenneth Weakley, said in a note to investors. Tenet's estimate of at least 25 percent growth in per-share profit in fiscal year 2003 takes into account a cut in the special Medicare payments, the company said after the market closed. Tenet, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., also left its forecasts for periods after 2003 unchanged.

headline.main: TENET HEALTHCARE SHARES FALL AFTER RATING IS CUT

docs.abstract: Shares of Tenet Healthcare Corp fall 14 percent after UBS Warburg analyst Kenneth Weakley cuts his rating on stock because of concern about government health care reimbursement to Tenet; Weakley says Tenet is more dependent than its rivals are on special Medicare payments for patients whose treatments cost much more than average (S)
